author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Here’s How Democrats’ Big Domestic Agenda Bill Has Shrunk
description: Proposed as a transformative, multitrillion-dollar plan with cradle-to-grave programs, Democrats’ domestic policy bill has been whittled down to a shadow of its former self.
content: WASHINGTON — Call it the incredible shrinking domestic policy initiative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daphne Merkin
title: Love and Carriage
description: A rarefied group of history buffs and horse enthusiasts meets in upstate New York for an annual drive with their horses.
content: I was never one of those little girls who devoured books or movies about horses, whether it was reading Anna Sewell’s 19th-century classic “Black Beauty” or watching a 12-year-old Elizabeth Taylor’s violet eyes sparkle with delight whenever she hugged her spirited gelding in “National Velvet.” The embarrassing truth is that I’m afraid of horses: of the way their eyes look out watchfully from the sides of their head, of their huge nostrils, of the possibility — faint but real — that they will sink their oversize yellow choppers into my soft flesh in a moment of skittishness or fear. As for horses and carriages, I had thought they were an artifact firmly of the past, like bustles and coachmen wearing powdered wigs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, David F. Gallagher and Jenny Gross
title: Biden, Oil and the Middle East
description: Under pressure as tight oil supplies hurt the U.S. economy, Biden will go to Saudi Arabia for a meeting with M.B.S.
content: JPMorgan Chase reported earnings this morning that were lower than forecasts, as it set aside bigger reserves to cover bad loans, a possible ominous sign for the rest of the banking sector. Its C.E.O., Jamie Dimon, said the bank was suspending share buybacks. Morgan Stanley’s earnings also fell short of expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: In ‘The Rehearsal,’ All the World Is Staged
description: The docu-comedy chaos agent Nathan Fielder returns, testing the idea that practice makes a perfect life.
content: Life, the philosopher Soren Kierkegaard once said, can be understood only backward, but it must be lived forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: John R. Froines, Chemist and Member of the Chicago Seven, Dies at 83
description: After his acquittal for inciting a riot at the 1968 Democratic National Convention, he became a leading environmental toxicologist, shaping government standards on lead and diesel exhaust.
content: John R. Froines, a quiet but politically stalwart chemist who stood trial alongside six other antiwar activists — known collectively as the Chicago Seven — on charges of conspiring to incite a riot during the 1968 Democratic National Convention, and who went on to become a pioneering advocate for environmental justice, died on Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: Stocks edge lower as bank earnings add to concerns about the economy.
description: Companies in the United States are starting to report their earnings for the second quarter, a chance for investors to assess how hard businesses are being hit by economic headwinds.
content: Stocks fell Thursday as investors grappled with the possibility of another higher-than-expected interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve and some downbeat earnings reports from major banks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: ‘Costa Brava, Lebanon’ Review: Paradise Tossed
description: In Mounia Akl’s ambitious debut feature, a family’s attempts to escape the filth of Beirut go awry when the garbage follows them to their doorstep.
content: As civic emergencies go, few possess the symbolic clarity of a garbage crisis. They’re ugly. They stink. They signify dysfunction, rot and toxicity in ways that need no sorting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing: Sri Lanka’s President Resigns
description: Plus President Biden treads carefully in Israel and Italy’s government nears collapse.
content: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka submitted his resignation by email from Singapore yesterday. He had fled his country early Wednesday after months of fervent protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: ‘Putin’s War Must Be a Strategic Failure,’ Biden Says in Israel
description: Ukraine policy has been a point of friction between Israel and the United States.
content: JERUSALEM — President Biden restated his determination that Russia fail in its Ukraine ambitions, speaking on Thursday during a four-day visit to Israel and Saudi Arabia in which he and other leaders discussed the international response to the war and the global grain shortage it has exacerbated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai and John Ismay
title: House Passes Bill to Expand Health Benefits for Burn Pit Exposure
description: The legislation would make millions of veterans exposed to the toxic pits eligible for medical and nursing home care, one of the largest expansions of benefits in history.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday passed a bill that would make millions of veterans who were exposed to trash burn pits on U.S. military bases around the world eligible for medical care, the most sweeping action by the federal government to recognize that the sites may have caused a range of diseases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: The Magic of Your First Work Friends
description: Early-career connections can be life-defining. For young people entering the work force today, the connections over Zoom are shaky.
content: The things that Lisa Degliantoni learned at 22 from the two best friends she met at her New York City publishing job included but were not limited to:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden and April Rubin
title: Storms Drench Southwest Virginia, With Flooding, Landslides and Home Damage
description: The authorities in Buchanan County said that the 44 people who were initially reported missing had all been located by Thursday, after flooding damaged more than 100 homes.
content: Dozens of people who had been initially reported missing had all been accounted for by Thursday afternoon, after powerful storms swept through southwestern Virginia, bringing heavy flooding and landslides and damaging more than 100 homes, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Biden’s Saudi Lesson: The Only Path Runs Through M.B.S.
description: President Biden tried to isolate Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman over human rights abuses. Now, the United States needs Saudi Arabia, and Mr. Biden is about to visit.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Saudi Arabia that President Biden will visit this week is a country being actively reshaped by the whims and visions of one man: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Trump: A Brat, but Not a Child
description: Trump should not escape responsibility for his self-imposed ignorance.
content: “President Trump is a 76-year-old man. He is not an impressionable child. Just like everyone else in our country, he is responsible for his own actions and his own choices.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘Paws of Fury: The Legend of Hank’ Review: A Tail of Two Samurai
description: Michael Cera and Samuel L. Jackson lend their voices to this unlikely animated adaptation of Mel Brooks’s “Blazing Saddles.”
content: Michael Cera stars as an anthropomorphic dog, who is in training to be a samurai, and Samuel L. Jackson plays his washed-up feline mentor in Paramount’s latest animated family flick, “Paws of Fury: The Legend of Hank.” The film sounds like standard CGI family fare, until you learn that the movie, originally titled “Blazing Samurai,” is a PG adaptation of Mel Brooks’s 1974 satire of Western films and race relations, “Blazing Saddles.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Claudia Gryvatz Copquin
title: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and on Long Island
description: This week’s available properties are a seven-bedroom mansion in Edgewater Park, N.J., and a four-bedroom farmhouse in Orient, N.Y.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Don’t Make Me Go’ Review: Sharp Curves Ahead for Next 2,000 Miles
description: John Cho and Mia Isaac play a father and daughter on a road trip in this twisty drama, which explores the gulf between familiarity and intimacy.
content: “You’re not going to like the way this story ends,” Wally (Mia Isaac), 15, warns the audience at the start of “Don’t Make Me Go,” a father-daughter drama of startling honesty and humor. Max (John Cho), Wally’s protective single dad, has learned that his headaches aren’t just from the struggle of parenting his restless teenager. A cancer diagnosis gives him one year to live — and instead of coming clean about his condition, Max packs up their wood-paneled Jeep for a road trip with an ulterior motive: To take a surprise detour to introduce Wally to her mother (Jen Van Epps), who ran away with Max’s best friend (Jemaine Clement) when the girl was an infant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Marc Tracy
title: ‘Top Gun: Maverick’ Enters the Pantheon of Conservative Fan Fiction
description: The American right has embraced Tom Cruise’s latest blockbuster, hailing the movie as a patriotic gesture produced in defiance of “woke” liberal elites and the Chinese Communist Party.
content: Today’s newsletter is a guest dispatch from the Culture desk of The New York Times. Marc Tracy, who regularly covers the intersection of culture and politics, writes about Tom Cruise’s latest blockbuster — and the conservatives who are singing its praises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: The U.S. accuses Russia of war crimes, alleging hundreds of thousands of Ukrainian deportations.
description: Ukrainian officials have long sounded the alarm on Russia’s deportations, but U.S. officials had previously been vague about their scale.
content: Russian authorities have  “interrogated,  detained, and forcibly deported” between 900,000 and 1.6 million Ukrainian citizens, including 260,000 children, from their homes into Russian territory, often to isolated regions in the far east, U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Democrats Face Deepening Peril as Republicans Seize on Inflation Fears
description: Economists warn that a blitz of midterm election campaign ads could push consumer prices even higher.
content: WASHINGTON — Triple-digit gasoline bills. Bulging hamburger prices. A Fourth of July holiday that broke the bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Isabel Kershner and Peter Baker
title: Israel urges the U.S. to put pressure on Iran.
description: Prime Minister Yair Lapid asked the U.S. to show Iran that it would take military action if Tehran continued its nuclear enrichment program, highlighting Israel’s opposition to U.S.-backed efforts to persuade Iran through diplomacy alone.
content: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Yair Lapid of Israel urged the United States on Thursday to show Iran that it would take military action if Tehran continued its nuclear enrichment program, highlighting Israel’s opposition to U.S.-backed efforts to persuade Iran through diplomacy alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Stubborn Divisions on Iran Don’t Cool Biden’s Warm Welcome in Israel
description: Amid declarations of the strong friendship between Israel and the United States, the differing approaches to the best way to stop Iran’s nuclear program were evident on Mr. Biden’s trip to Jerusalem.
content: JERUSALEM — President Biden on Thursday issued one of the bluntest warnings to Tehran of his presidency, committing to Israel’s leaders that “we will not allow Iran to acquire a nuclear weapon,” but Israel’s caretaker prime minister, Yair Lapid, pushed even further, asking all democratic nations to vow to act if the Iranians continue “to develop their nuclear program.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Texas Sues Biden Administration Over Access to Emergency Medical Abortions
description: Recent administrative guidance to hospitals said doctors could perform abortions in emergency situations if complications posed a threat to the health or life of the mother.
content: HOUSTON — Days after the Biden administration moved to ensure access to abortion in certain emergency situations, Attorney General Ken Paxton of Texas on Thursday filed a lawsuit challenging the federal guidance, saying it would “force abortions” in hospitals in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Mrs. Harris Goes to Paris’ Review: High Fashion for the Humble
description: This inspirational comedy starring Lesley Manville and Isabelle Huppert trades in a similar kind of British coziness as the “Paddington” movies, though it’s not nearly as effective.
content: In “Mrs. Harris Goes to Paris,” Lesley Manville returns to the world of high fashion in a reversal of her Oscar-nominated role in “Phantom Thread.” Her deliciously frigid character in that film — the forbidding manager of a British fashion house and foe to Vicky Krieps’s lowborn muse — would go catatonic were Manville’s Mrs. Ada Harris to waltz into the fitting room, asking for a “frock” with her cockney drawl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger and Eve Washington
title: The Housing Shortage Isn’t Just a Coastal Crisis Anymore
description: An increasingly national problem has consequences for the quality of American family life, the economy and the future of housing politics.
content: San Francisco, Los Angeles, New York and Washington have long failed to build enough housing to keep up with everyone trying to live there. And for nearly as long, other parts of the country have mostly been able to shrug off the housing shortage as a condition particular to big coastal cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: As Y Chromosomes Vanish With Age, Heart Risks May Grow
description: A study of mice might explain why.
content: It’s been known for more than half a century that many men lose their Y chromosomes as they age. But no one knew if it really mattered. The loss of Y could just be a sign of aging, like gray hair, with no clinical relevance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Persuasion’ Review: The Present Intrudes Into the Past
description: Dakota Johnson smirks her way through a Netflix adaptation of the rekindled romance in Jane Austen’s last novel, our critic writes.
content: The great irony of this new, not-quite-modernized adaptation of Jane Austen’s final novel, “Persuasion,” is that it communicates its tense relationship to its 19th-century source material in a repressed, passive-aggressive manner — an approach oddly suited to Austen’s trenchant view of society. The film doesn’t take the creative leap to transpose the beloved story in the present day. Instead, in curiously excruciating fashion, the director, screenwriters, and star imply their discomfort with Georgian-era social norms from within the novel’s period setting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: A Combative Macron Seeks to Dispel Worries of Second-Term Drift
description: In a televised Bastille Day interview, the French president sought to reassure a country buffeted by rising inflation, scorching temperatures and uncertain political waters.
content: PARIS — In his first televised interview since his re-election, President Emmanuel Macron of France adopted a combative tone on Thursday in trying to reassure the French that he was firmly at the wheel to address challenges ranging from inflation to climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Ex-Georgia Mayor Gets Nearly 5 Years in Prison for Stealing Covid Relief Money
description: Jason Lary used hundreds of thousands of dollars of federal funds to pay off the mortgage on his lakefront home and outstanding taxes, the authorities said.
content: The former mayor of Stonecrest, Ga., a small city outside Atlanta, was sentenced on Wednesday to four years and nine months in prison for stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars in federal money intended to help his city cope with the pandemic, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Celia McGee
title: A Photographer Follows Paul Revere Williams Into the West
description: The architect’s achievements transformed the landscape of Nevada but were obscured by racism. Janna Ireland’s exhibition changes that.
content: Paul Revere Williams came by his nickname “architect to the stars” over a career that saw his designs dot the wealthiest enclaves of Southern California, leaving a silver-screen-size impact during the decades coinciding with Hollywood’s golden era. He created homes for Frank Sinatra and Lucille Ball, among others, and helped erect elegant municipal, federal and commercial developments as far afield as Washington, D.C. In two best-selling books, he championed affordable housing for a new generation of homeowners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Earwig’ Review: Danse Macabre
description: The latest trip down the rabbit hole by the French director Lucile Hadzihalilovic follows a young girl with teeth made of ice and her cadaverous caretaker.
content: Near the beginning of “Earwig,” the latest trip down the darkest of rabbit holes by the French director Lucile Hadzihalilovic, a 10-year-old girl admires a landscape painting, seated before it in an image similar to the famous scene from “Poltergeist.” Fascinated, she runs her fingers over the rough canvas and its vibrant colors; it’s a moment not unlike the experience of watching the film, which can feel like being hypnotized by disturbingly palpable still lifes from the unconscious realm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: The Webb Telescope Restored (Some of) My Faith in Humanity
description: The machine that’s a low-key a triumph of the human spirit.
content: The James Webb Space Telescope is a triumph. It is the most powerful space telescope ever built, capable of looking back almost to the beginning of time, and it will alter if not revolutionize humanity’s understanding of the most fundamental questions about existence: How did the universe become the way it is? Is ours the only world with life? Also, asking for a friend, is there anywhere nearby we might be able to escape to?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘From Where They Stood’ Review: Auschwitz, as Seen by Prisoners
description: Christophe Cognet’s documentary pores over photographs, some of them clandestine, taken by prisoners, inside the Nazi concentration camp.
content: Christophe Cognet’s “From Where They Stood” scrutinizes an astonishing record of the Holocaust: photographs secretly taken by prisoners within Auschwitz-Birkenau and other concentration camps. Cognet’s analytical documentary adopts the stance of an investigating historian to explicate the pictures, which were made and smuggled out at mortal risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Impossible Task of Keeping Up With the Ingebrigtsens
description: The Kardashians of Norway are middle-distance runners who have competed on the global stage. But it’s Jakob, 21, who transformed from onetime prodigy to generational talent.
content: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz. — Jakob Ingebrigtsen is surrounded by silence, all those empty spaces between workouts and competitions. As the fastest miler in the world, he is aware of the peculiarities of his profession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: Which States Are the Most Safe and Secure for Renters?
description: A recent study examined natural disasters, eviction rates and rental laws to determine where U.S. renters could feel most at home.
content: The United States has experienced nine weather or climate disasters so far this year that have caused at least $1 billion in damages, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The agency also reported that above-normal temperatures were in the forecast for most of the country this summer. With extreme weather on the rise, people may be wondering which areas are safer than others to find a new home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Janet Yellen Says It’s in Russia’s Interest to Go Along With an Oil Price Cap
description: Facing sanctions on its exports, Russia could continue selling oil profitably under a cap, the U.S. Treasury secretary said, while global strains on supply and pressure on prices would reduce.
content: On the eve of a meeting of finance chiefs from the world’s major economies in Bali, Indonesia, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen continued to push for a price cap on Russian oil, calling it “one of our most powerful tools” to alleviate the painful leaps in energy and food prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Has remote work changed your relationships with colleagues?
description: Tell us about your experience with work friendships when you’re not in the office.
content: Office occupancy across the United States is still less than 50 percent of its prepandemic levels. Many people are working from home, which comes as a relief to some workers while others find it harder to socialize with their colleagues. Some have found inventive ways of staying connected, whether through virtual gatherings, instant messaging or in-person retreats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: A 10-Year-Old Endures the Predictable Result of an Abortion Ban
description: Why is the right in denial about what their laws do?
content: Not long after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, an Indiana obstetrician and gynecologist named Caitlin Bernard told The Indianapolis Star about a call she’d gotten from a doctor in Ohio. The Ohio doctor had a 10-year-old patient who was six weeks and three days pregnant. An Ohio law banning abortion after fetal cardiac activity can be detected — usually around the sixth week of pregnancy — had just gone into effect, so the girl needed to cross state lines for care. The report, being illustrative of the ghoulish impact of abortion prohibitions, went viral, and Joe Biden mentioned it in a speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italy’s Unity Government Teeters, as Mario Draghi Offers to Resign
description: The country’s president refused to accept the prime minister’s resignation, leaving the country in political limbo.
content: ROME — Italy’s golden period of stability suddenly seemed on the familiar precipice of chaos on Thursday after Prime Minister Mario Draghi tendered his resignation in response to a revolt by anti-establishment populists within his broad national unity government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: South Carolina Lawyer Alex Murdaugh Charged With Killing Wife and Son
description: Scrutiny of last year’s murders remained high as Mr. Murdaugh was indicted on a series of financial crimes and the police re-examined the deaths of several people associated with the family.
content: Alex Murdaugh, the fourth-generation lawyer whose family has long held power and influence in a rural swath of South Carolina, was charged on Thursday with killing his wife and one of his sons at the family’s secluded hunting estate in a mysterious murder that remained unsolved for more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: A British Open Green With One Last Catch: A 150-Foot Putt
description: The St. Andrews quirk of double greens offers thrills and aggravations whenever the world’s elite go to the Old Course.
content: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The wind can go from negligible to middling to mighty on the Old Course. It may very well rain, or look like it will, and for how long is anyone’s guess. People dressed in layers — this is Scotland in July, after all — pass sunscreen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Biden calls for a ‘lasting negotiated peace’ between Israel and the Palestinians.
description: He also reiterated his calls for a two-state solution to the conflict.
content: JERUSALEM — President Biden called on Thursday for a “lasting negotiated peace between the State of Israel and the Palestinian people” and reiterated his calls for a two-state solution to the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin, John Liu and Amy Chang Chien
title: China’s Surveillance State Hits Rare Resistance From Its Own Subjects
description: Beijing’s swift move to censor news about one of the largest known data breaches shows keen awareness of how major security lapses can harm its credibility.
content: Chinese artists have staged performances to highlight the ubiquity of surveillance cameras. Privacy activists have filed lawsuits against the collection of facial recognition data. Ordinary citizens and establishment intellectuals alike have pushed back against the abuse of Covid tracking apps by the authorities to curb protests. Internet users have shared tips on how to evade digital monitoring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Hidden Artwork Revealed by X-Ray Appears to Be Van Gogh Self-Portrait, Experts Say
description: A conservator at the National Galleries of Scotland uncovered the painting on the back of another one by the Dutch artist.
content: AMSTERDAM — There were 35 known self-portraits of Vincent van Gogh in the world. That appears to have changed this week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A London Restaurant Inspired by Ghana’s Chop Bars
description: Plus: a clothing store with a Greek cafe, furniture fashioned from branches and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Semiconductor Problem
description: The military relies on advanced semiconductors. The U.S. doesn’t make any.
content: The most advanced category of mass-produced semiconductors — used in smartphones, military technology and much more — is known as 5 nm. A single company in Taiwan, known as TSMC, makes about 90 percent of them. U.S. factories make none.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Queen of Glory’ Review: Back to the Bronx
description: In the writer-director Nana Mensah’s amusing and astute feature debut, a death forces a reckoning for a brainy young Ghanaian-American living in both worlds.
content: Molecular neuro-oncologist Sarah Obeng is very smart. But in the subtle delight “Queen of Glory” — written and directed by its lead actor, Nana Mensah — the American daughter of Ghanaian parents can be foolish, too. Take her married boyfriend and university colleague, Lyle (Adam Leon): He’s simply not worthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Petrow
title: My Dog’s Death Taught Me Spiritual Detachment. Then My Sister Got Sick.
description: When she got cancer, she started joking about life without her. I was not amused.
content: Shortly after my parents died in 2017, I nearly lost custody of my dog, Zoe, in my divorce. When we were reunited, I remember telling her firmly, “You cannot die now,” even though she had just turned 15.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Anonymous Club’ Review: The Joy of Creation
description: The Australian singer-songwriter Courtney Barnett goes on a world tour in this music documentary, and finds that a change is needed.
content: The singer-songwriter Courtney Barnett started out as a DIY artist, home-recording energetic songs communicating knotty feelings. Early in this documentary, written and directed by Danny Cohen, a cheery interviewer leads into a question by saying that it’s not too common to hear artists “singing about panic attacks.” This reflects more on the limited listening experience of the interviewer than anything else, but you get the idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Lauren Boebert’s Gun-Themed Restaurant, Shooters Grill, Closes
description: The building’s landlord decided not to renew Ms. Boebert’s lease for the restaurant.
content: Shooters Grill, a restaurant owned by Representative Lauren Boebert of Colorado where waitresses with guns holstered on their hips served “Shotgun” burritos, “Locked N’ Loaded Nachos,” “Swiss & Wesson” burgers and “Rifle Toast,” closed on Sunday after the building’s landlord decided not to renew the lease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Kevin Spacey Pleads Not Guilty to Sexual Assault
description: The Oscar-winning actor will face a trial in June 2023 — a rare example of a celebrity #MeToo case reaching that stage in Britain.
content: LONDON — Kevin Spacey, the Oscar and Tony Award-winning actor, pleaded not guilty to charges of sexual assault on Thursday, British prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: U.S. Electric Car Sales Climb Sharply Despite Shortages
description: A scarcity of semiconductors and raw materials held back production, but buyers remain enthusiastic.
content: Americans are buying electric vehicles at a record pace, undeterred by rising prices and long waits for delivery, a further indication that the twilight of the internal combustion engine is on the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Teen Arrested in Fatal Shooting of Man Who Swung Bat at Squeegee Workers
description: The victim had a heated confrontation with the street workers as he drove through a downtown intersection in Baltimore. The police said he approached the group with a baseball bat and swung it at them.
content: A teenager has been arrested and charged in connection with the fatal shooting of a driver who confronted squeegee workers with a baseball bat in Baltimore earlier this month, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Schoenfeld
title: ‘Drive to Survive’ Made Americans Fall in Love With Formula 1
description: The Netflix show sold the European sport to a U.S. audience. But will the romance last after the series is gone?
content: One Thursday morning in May, the Formula 1 driver Valtteri Bottas was enjoying an alfresco breakfast with his girlfriend, the cyclist Tiffany Cromwell, on the secluded terrace of a South Beach hotel. It was a last bit of vacation before the start of practice sessions for that weekend’s Miami Grand Prix. Bottas and Cromwell had spent an hour biking along the beach. Now they were sitting under a trellis of bougainvillea, chatting casually in the way that romantic partners do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Russia Gets Closer to Iran
description: Our U.N. correspondent explains the changing dynamic between the two countries.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: In an era of alphabet soup diplomacy, Biden is adding ingredients.
description: Unsettled times have brought a proliferation of new clusters of various countries, and the acronyms that come with them.
content: JERUSALEM — This is what international diplomacy has come to in the era of President Biden, also known as POTUS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Barbara Kruger: A Way With Words
description: She created some of the most memorable works of her era. Now the activist-artist is back with two immersive shows, at MoMA and David Zwirner Gallery.
content: Barbara Kruger has changed the way the world looks — its visual language, including art, advertising and graphic design. She has been less successful in changing the way the world works, especially regarding gender injustices — the oppression of women in its infinite variety, the dominance of men (ditto) — and such plagues as war, consumerism and poverty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: The S.E.C. broadens its inquiry into Elon Musk’s disclosures about Twitter.
description: The agency questioned whether a tweet Mr. Musk sent in May about the acquisition of Twitter should have been disclosed to the agency and investors.
content: The Securities and Exchange Commission has broadened its inquiry into whether Elon Musk properly disclosed his investment in Twitter and his intentions for the social media company, the agency revealed on Thursday in a filing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Man Exonerated in Malcolm X Murder Sues New York City After Talks Fail
description: Muhammad A. Aziz filed the $40 million claim on Thursday, seeking redress for a conviction that overshadowed 55 years of his life.
content: New York’s criminal justice system took 55 years to acknowledge that it had wrongly branded Muhammad A. Aziz as one of Malcolm X’s killers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Marx Can Wait’ Review: A Director Digs Into His Brother’s Death
description: In a moving new documentary, the Italian filmmaker Marco Bellocchio gathers his fascinating, aging family members to make sense of their brother’s suicide.
content: Sometime in the late 1960s, Camillo Bellocchio confided in his twin brother, Marco, that he was unhappy with the way his life was going. Marco, already a well-known filmmaker and a committed leftist, counseled Camillo, who was managing a gym, to throw himself into radical politics and seek solace in the “historical optimism” of the revolutionary proletariat. Camillo doubted that his anguish could be healed through political engagement. “Marx can wait,” he told his brother. Not long after, Camillo died by suicide. He was 29.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Facts Were Sparse on an Abortion Case. But That Didn’t Stop the Attacks.
description: The story of a 10-year-old girl in Ohio became the focus of a heated political debate that played out in the news media.
content: For nearly two weeks, the story of a 10-year-old Ohio girl who was raped and crossed state lines to get an abortion became a flash point in the national abortion debate. President Biden and other Democrats argued that it showed the harm resulting from the Supreme Court’s overturning of Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Monty Norman, Who Wrote 007’s Memorable Theme, Dies at 94
description: He composed the instantly recognizable melody for the first James Bond film, “Dr. No.” It has accompanied the agent on his adventures ever since.
content: Monty Norman, who in the early 1960s reached into his back catalog, pulled out a song about a sneeze and transformed it into one of the most recognizable bits of music in movie history, the “James Bond Theme,” died on Monday in Slough, near London. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: Revisiting the Pyramids’ ‘Avant-Garde African Jazz,’ Four Decades Later
description: The group that started at Antioch College in Ohio went to Africa and returned “transformed,” one of its members said. A new boxed set collects its little-heard albums from the 1970s.
content: In the early 1970s, as many jazz musicians looked directly to Africa for rhythms and inspiration, a group of students from Antioch College pushed even further, creating music that was so overtly African, you would have thought it was coming direct from Kenya or Senegal, not a small liberal arts college in Yellow Springs, Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Gabby Giffords Won’t Back Down’ Review: A New Mission
description: This documentary from the directors of “RBG” offers a window into the life of the former Democratic congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords after she survived a bullet wound to the head.
content: In 2011, Gabrielle Giffords, then a Democratic congresswoman, was hosting a public meet-and-greet outside a Safeway supermarket in Arizona when a gunman opened fire into the gathering, killing six people and wounding many more. Giffords suffered a bullet to the head that shattered her skull and wreaked havoc on the left side of her brain. She now struggles with aphasia, a condition that interferes with the expression of language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: ‘The Deer King’ Review: Medicine, Family and Empire
description: A series of Japanese fantasy novels is the basis for this tenderly wrought and brilliantly animated adventure movie.
content: Based on a series of fantasy books by the Japanese author Nahoko Uehashi, the animated film “The Deer King” opens on a chain gang of enslaved people forced to labor in a salt mine. While they and their captors sleep, a pack of wolves enter the mine, biting hundreds and passing on a deadly disease. A pair of humans manage to get out alive: Van (Shinichi Tsutsumi), a former soldier, and Yuna (Hisui Kimura), an orphaned toddler. The two escape to the countryside, only to find themselves thrust into an effort to discover a cure for the disease that killed the others. The movie, directed by Masashi Ando and Masayuki Miyaji, follows Van’s tender relationship with Yuna and the lengths he will go to protect her, even as he finds nefarious forces stacked against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: House Passes $840 Billion Military Policy Bill
description: The House moved to increase President Biden’s requested Pentagon budget by $37 billion, reflecting a growing bipartisan appetite in Congress to raise military spending.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday passed an $840 billion policy bill that would increase President Biden’s requested Pentagon budget by $37 billion, reflecting a growing bipartisan appetite in Congress to raise military spending amid new threats from Russia and China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Pogacar Attacks Tour Leader on Iconic Climb, to No Avail
description: The picturesque switchbacks and enthusiastic crowds on the ride to Alpe d’Huez make it the most famous climb in cycling.
content: Tadej Pogacar held his fire on the Galibier. He waited through the Croix de Fer. He sat tight during the 60-mile-an-hour descents after those brutal climbs. For more than four and a half hours, he did not make a move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yair Listokin and Jonathon Zytnick
title: Elon Musk Bought Twitter. Now He Must Own It.
description: A deal of this magnitude can generate value for Twitter and create stability for future mergers.
content: Elon Musk is trying to walk away from his $44 billion agreement to buy Twitter, but the Court of Chancery in Delaware, where the company is incorporated and is now suing Mr. Musk, should order him to buy the social media company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Markets Shrugged Off Bad Inflation News
description: An ugly report may not be the shape of things to come.
content: Another month, another bad consumer price report. Media headlines screamed about 9.1 percent inflation, and the numbers for June were, in fact, bad no matter how you cut them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel is between governments (again). Will Biden’s visit help the interim leader get elected?
description: President Biden’s visit during an Israeli election campaign may have been unavoidable, given that voters are heading to the polls for a fifth time in under four years.
content: JERUSALEM — President Biden, who prides himself on having known every Israeli prime minister over half a century, met on Thursday with a new one: Yair Lapid, the leader of a caretaker government.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: It’s purely a coincidence, I swear, that our recommended books this week include a novel named “Elsewhere” and a memoir named “Son of Elsewhere” — but as coincidences go, it’s a pretty resonant one, no? Wherever we are these days, it seems, we all want to be anywhere but here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: How to Invest When Inflation Is Bad and a Recession May Loom
description: While the news may indicate that the markets and economy are rocky, long-term investors can ride it out with a little luck and a lot of planning, our columnist says.
content: The news on inflation has been bad for months, but it’s recently gotten worse. On Wednesday, the government reported that in June the Consumer Price Index rose at an annual rate of 9.1 percent — the fastest pace since November 1981.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Netanyahu met with Biden, offering praise and a warning.
description: The U.S. president has often spoken fondly of Israel’s former prime minister, but relations between the two have also had low points.
content: President Biden has finished meeting with Israel’s opposition leader, former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: France Faces a Shortage of Mustard, Its Uniquely Beloved Condiment
description: A perfect storm of climate change, a European war and Covid have left the French scrambling for alternatives.
content: PARIS — Mustard runs deep in French culture. “My blood is boiling” is rendered in French by the expression “la moutarde me monte au nez,” or “the mustard is rising into my nose” — and as Bastille Day testifies, when that happens in France, the effect can be devastating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Brittney Griner’s case shows the limits of American power.
description: As outrage mounts over Brittney Griner’s continued detention in Russia, many in America have wondered publicly if U.S. officials could be doing more to secure Griner’s release. LeBron James, the argument goes, would have been freed long ago.
content: As outrage mounts over Brittney Griner’s continued detention in Russia, many in America have wondered publicly if U.S. officials could be doing more to secure Griner’s release. LeBron James, the argument goes, would have been freed long ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Avignon Festival Gets Its Buzz Back
description: With striking premieres in the main program and enchanting discoveries on the supplementary Fringe, the eminent event in European theater is flourishing after some difficult years.
content: AVIGNON, France — After two years of pandemic-related disruption, the Avignon Festival is well and truly back. As the event, a longtime highlight on the European theater calendar, got underway here last week, there were familiar sights everywhere. All around the small city center, buzzing crowds filled the streets, while blasé regulars zigzagged between performers handing out fliers for some 1,570 Fringe productions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Jerome M. Eisenberg, Expert on Antiquities Both Real and Fake, Dies at 92
description: He saw himself as a leader in promoting the ethical acquisition of ancient art by museums and collectors, although he also called himself “both an idealist and a hypocrite.”
content: Jerome M. Eisenberg, a leading New York antiquities dealer who in the murky world of tomb raiders and smugglers held himself up as a guardian against the illegal importation and sale of ancient art, died on July 6, his 92nd birthday, in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: In Battle to Beat Democratic Titans, a Lawyer in Sneakers Bets on Youth
description: New Yorkers are witnessing an epic primary clash between Representatives Jerrold Nadler and Carolyn Maloney. Suraj Patel is trying to eke out his own path to victory.
content: Suraj Patel has few illusions about what he’s up against as he takes on two titans of New York politics, Representatives Carolyn Maloney and Jerrold Nadler, in this summer’s blockbuster Democratic primary. But he does take hope from a theory about coffee shops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘First Person'
title: His Ship Finally Came In, but Should He Be on It?
description: The pandemic marooned Charles Falls Jr. on land for nearly two years. Now, he’s setting sail again.
content: Since the pandemic started, we’ve all had to make endless decisions about what is worth the risk: eat out, or stay home; attend a best friend’s wedding, or watch the livestream; go on vacation, or cancel it — again. But going into Year 3, that calculus has lost its urgency for many people. This summer’s chaotic travel season is evidence enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic recommends a quirky comedy, a sweeping outdoor adventure show and a sports documentary about a real-life “Ted Lasso”-type story.
content: ‘Shrink’When to watch: Now, Peacock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Janeane Garofalo Never Sold Out. What a Relief.
description: That concept might be the reason her trailblazing stand-up career has been overshadowed; it may also be the reason she’s still so sharp, our critic argues.
content: On a rainy Wednesday night in Brooklyn, after an introduction with a minimum of fanfare, Janeane Garofalo walked onstage at the Eastville Comedy Club and looked out at a dozen people so scattered that calling them a crowd seems like a stretch. She spotted one man by himself who had attended a show of hers a few days earlier and happily pointed him out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Britain Braces for ‘Exceptionally’ Hot Weather
description: The Met Office issued an amber warning for extreme heat this weekend.
content: LONDON — Put a hat on. Slather on the sunscreen, and drink plenty of water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Walther
title: The Big Ten Is Growing, but All I See Is Decline
description: The identities of collegiate conferences are disappearing like regional accents.
content: Philip Larkin once wrote that all historians of jazz are either H.G. Wells or Edward Gibbon — “onwards and upwards, or decline and fall.” It’s the relentless progress of Wells’s “Outline of History” or the inexorable doom of Gibbon’s Roman Empire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: For a Woman in a Wheelchair, Abortion Access Was One More Challenge
description: Roxanne Schiebergen, a writer and actress, has become skilled at navigating New York City since she was a student at N.Y.U. Then came an unexpected pregnancy.
content: Roxanne Schiebergen, a 30-year-old writer and actress who lives in New York, was in the bathroom of her Midtown apartment when she received a text from a close friend one day in May. The text included a screenshot of a marketing flyer promoting a “Bans Off Our Bodies” rally sponsored in part by Planned Parenthood. The photo in the ad showed four women — and the woman at the center was in a wheelchair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A watchdog report absolves financial transactions made by two top Fed officials.
description: The Fed’s chair and vice chair did not violate any rules, the report found. Still, some found the description of the vice chair’s trades unsatisfying.
content: A review from the Federal Reserve’s watchdog found that trades made by two top officials in 2019 and 2020, when the central bank was especially active in financial markets, violated neither the law nor central bank policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Tech Magic That Unleashed Your Best
description: Our readers tell us about the surprising ways in which tech has helped them discover new worlds.
content: Last week, our On Tech editor, Hanna Ingber, shared a story of her kiddo stumbling upon a design app that unlocked his amazing taste for interiors. We asked for your own tales of surprising ways in which technology helped you unleash creativity or discover new joys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What Californians Need to Know About Monkeypox
description: More than 150 cases have been reported so far in the state, and most are in San Francisco or Los Angeles.
content: By now you’ve probably heard of monkeypox, the latest disease making headlines as it spreads across the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Municipal Workers Have Joined the Great Resignation
description: New York City employees are back in the office, and many of them are not happy about it.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at why municipal workers in New York City are quitting. We’ll also meet someone who’s not rattled by rattlesnakes, on the job or off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kaminer
title: Toronto Steps Into Summer
description: It’s the city’s traditional high season and it is celebrating with newly opened hotels and restaurants and a revived live-performance scene.
content: Canada’s biggest city and North America’s fourth-largest metropolis, Toronto received more than 27.5 million visitors annually before the pandemic, making it Canada’s top tourism destination, according to Destination Toronto, the city’s tourism-marketing arm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A Fed Governor Signals a Full-Point Rate Increase Is Possible, but Not Yet His Call
description: Christopher Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, could support an even bigger July rate increase than the Fed’s large June move if economic data continue to come in hot.
content: Christopher Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, said he supported increasing the central bank’s policy interest rate in July by the same amount as in June, though he suggested that an even larger move could be warranted if economic data continued to come in hot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Americans Are Hungry for Change, So Get Ready for More Turmoil
description: For the White House in 2024, think outsider and unconventional.
content: I’d like you to consider the possibility that the political changes that have rocked this country over the past six years will be nothing compared with the changes that will rock it over the next six. I’d like you to consider the possibility that we’re in some sort of prerevolutionary period — the kind of moment that often gives birth to something shocking and new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria M. Walker
title: W.N.B.A. Adds Charter Flights for the Finals. Here Is Why That Matters.
description: Teams usually fly on commercial airlines, but that will change for the W.N.B.A. finals. This could be good news for players’ health, finances and game.
content: Delay after delay. Then, a cancellation. Germy bathrooms. Wrestling with yourself over paying $4 for a small bag of Skittles. Forgetting your headphones and wanting to cry. Now, the power plug at your seat is not working, and the people sitting next to you on the airplane won’t stop coughing. Do they have Covid?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: ‘French Girl Beauty’ Has a New Offering
description: Garance Doré, one of the original style bloggers, has released a beauty line based on her favorite pharmacy brands.
content: In 2019, Garance Doré went on a silent retreat. Over the course of six days at Spirit Rock in Northern California, she had a hard time not speaking to Emily Yeston, her roommate and business partner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘She Will’ Review: Payback Is a Witch
description: A traumatized star is supernaturally primed for vengeance in this gorgeously ghostly thriller.
content: The first name we see onscreen in “She Will” belongs not to its director (Charlotte Colbert) or its star (Alice Krige), but to one of its executive producers, the horror maestro Dario Argento. And it doesn’t take long to recognize the ways in which the plot of this confident first feature (written by Colbert and Kitty Percy) might have appealed to Argento: The emphasis on dreams, the sly humor and — perhaps most of all — the despoilment of female beauty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Differing views of a Ukrainian nationalist’s role in the Holocaust expose divisions over the past.
description: BERLIN — It was as if Ukraine’s ambassador in Germany was vying for the title of most undiplomatic diplomat: Determined to spur Berlin into more urgent support for his embattled nation, he mocked the chancellor, told a former lawmaker to “shut your trap,” and posted memes on Twitter likening Germany’s lagging weapons deliveries to a snail with a bullet taped to its back.
content: BERLIN — It was as if Ukraine’s ambassador in Germany was vying for the title of most undiplomatic diplomat: Determined to spur Berlin into more urgent support for his embattled nation, he mocked the chancellor, told a former lawmaker to “shut your trap,” and posted memes on Twitter likening Germany’s lagging weapons deliveries to a snail with a bullet taped to its back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: How Mo Farah Outran His Sad Beginnings
description: The distance runner, who said this week that he was trafficked to the United Kingdom as a child, trained under Alberto Salazar on his way to becoming a four-time Olympic gold medalist.
content: My first meeting with him was inadvertent, clandestine. It occurred in Albuquerque in October 2010. I had traveled there to write about another runner, the American Dathan Ritzenhein, as he trained for that year’s New York City Marathon with his new coach, Alberto Salazar, a former star who had morphed into an eccentric tailor, making alterations to Ritzenhein’s posture and stride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes for Sale in New York City
description: This week’s available properties are in Downtown Brooklyn, Hell’s Kitchen and Lenox Hill.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Firefighters Are Using Sprinklers to Protect A Treasured Giant Sequoia in Yosemite
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday July 14, 2022.
content: ‘I’ve counted a lot of dead giant sequoias, and I don’t like it. It’s like counting dead people. It clobbered me.’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and Michael Levenson
title: Strikes on Civilians Deep in Ukraine Show Russia’s Lethal Reach
description: Missiles struck Vinnytsia, hundreds of miles from the front lines, and other cities, claiming dozens of lives, as Russia keeps up pressure despite pausing its eastern offensive.
content: VINNYTSIA, Ukraine — A volley of missiles hit a shopping center, a dance studio and a wedding hall in central Ukraine on Thursday, killing at least 23 people and setting off a frantic search for dozens more missing in the rubble, in the latest strike to hit civilian targets far from the front line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King and Jonathan Weisman
title: Young Voters Are Fed Up With Their (Much) Older Leaders
description: Led by politicians often three times their age, many voters under 30 are hungry for new blood and new ideas.
content: Alexandra Chadwick went to the polls in 2020 with the single goal of ousting Donald J. Trump. A 22-year-old first-time voter, she saw Joseph R. Biden Jr. as more of a safeguard than an inspiring political figure, someone who could stave off threats to abortion access, gun control and climate policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Bank of America is fined $225 million for mishandling pandemic unemployment benefits.
description: An automated fraud filter improperly froze thousands of customers’ accounts, regulators said.
content: Two federal regulators fined Bank of America $225 million on Thursday for mishandling prepaid debit card accounts used by a dozen states to distribute unemployment benefits during the pandemic, and the bank must compensate people for damages, an amount likely to total hundreds of millions more, federal officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: The W.H.O. warns against ‘apathy’ in efforts to contain Covid in Africa.
description: The warning came two days after the W.H.O., a United Nations agency, declared that Covid-19 was still a global public health emergency that was not going anywhere.
content: With coronavirus case counts climbing and vaccination efforts lagging in some African nations, regional officials of the World Health Organization issued a warning on Thursday against lax enforcement of public health measures to curb the pandemic on the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Man With Meth in His System Drove Truck That Killed 9, Officials Say
description: The authorities initially believed that the man’s 13-year-old son was behind the wheel of the truck that crashed into a van carrying a college golf team in Texas in March.
content: A 38-year-old man with methamphetamine in his system — not his 13-year-old son — was driving a truck in Andrews County, Texas, in March that struck a van, killing nine people, including himself, the boy, six members of a college golf team and its coach, the authorities said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: What are the Maccabiah Games?
description: Israel’s biggest sporting event, which President Biden is scheduled to attend on Thursday evening, is often referred to as the Jewish Olympics.
content: The Maccabiah Games, which President Biden attended on Thursday evening, are Israel’s biggest sporting event, often referred to as the Jewish Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: The Mysteriously Low Death Toll of the Heat Waves in India and Pakistan
description: Many of our assumptions about deaths from extreme heat may be wrong.
content: It’s monsoon season now in India, which means it is possible to look back on the extraordinary succession of heat waves that swept across South Asia starting this spring — and begin, at least, to take stock of their impact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Naroditsky
title: Chess Replay: You Versus Bronstein
description: Take on David Bronstein in a recreation of an 18th World Championship game in Moscow, 1951. Solve for the best series of moves.
content: This is Chess Replay, an interactive puzzle based on a historic chess game. As a solver, you embody a famous player during a critical game in his or her career. A new edition of this puzzle is published each week on Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila S. Coronel
title: The Philippines Has a New Liar in Chief
description: Truth and accountability will not be hallmarks of Marcos 2.0.
content: When Ferdinand Marcos Jr. was sworn in as president of the Philippines on June 30, he took his oath in front of the former legislative building where his father entered politics and swore on the same Bible used by the elder Mr. Marcos at his 1965 inauguration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Random coronavirus testing will resume for international passengers arriving in Canada at four major airports.
description: The country’s mandatory testing program was paused last month as the government worked to shift the testing out of Canada’s busy airport terminals.
content: Mandatory coronavirus testing of randomly chosen international passengers arriving in Canada will resume at the country’s four major airports, government officials announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Science and Data Change Soccer’s Definition of Old
description: Top clubs have long looked to shed players once they hit age 30. But those presumptions rely on outdated logic, statistics show.
content: LONDON — The exact location of the threshold has always been contested. At Manchester United, for a time, it lurked close enough to 30 for that to serve as a natural watershed. Once players hit their 30s, Alex Ferguson, the club’s manager at the time, tended to grant them an extra day’s rest after a game, in the hope that the break might soothe their creaking bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Clare Toeniskoetter, Carlos Prieto, Rikki Novetsky, Rachelle Bonja, Jessica Cheung, Asthaa Chaturvedi, John Ketchum, M.J. Davis Lin, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: How Sri Lanka’s Economy Collapsed
description: Amid food and fuel shortages, a protest movement has pushed for the resignation of the president and others tied to his family’s political dynasty.
content: In recent days, the political crisis in Sri Lanka has reached a critical point, with its president fleeing the country and protesters occupying his residence and office. Today, “The Daily” explores how the island nation, whose economy was once held up as a success story in South Asia, came apart — and why it’s a cautionary tale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky, Ivan Nechepurenko, Tania Ganguli and Anton Troianovski
title: Witnesses testify in Brittney Griner’s defense as her drug trial continues in Russia.
description: The case of an American sports star at the mercy of Russian justice has rippled across the world amid criticism from Washington that she has been wrongfully detained.
content: Witnesses for the defense praised Brittney Griner’s athletic prowess and character on Thursday in a courtroom outside Moscow, where the American basketball star — now one of the world’s most famous prisoners — is facing a possible 10-year sentence on drug charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘Zombies 3’ Review: Take Me to Your Cheerleader
description: In the final installment of this Disney trilogy, the arrival of aliens alters our high school heroes’ quests for college — and social — acceptance.
content: In “Zombies 3,” directed by Paul Hoen, an interspecies utopia faces an alien invasion. Like the franchise’s previous allegories for marginalized experiences — the zombies of “Zombies” and werewolves of “Zombies 2” share hardships with Black and Indigenous Americans, respectively — this one is dubious at best.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Secret Service Text Messages Around Jan. 6 Were Erased, Inspector General Says
description: The disclosure drew concern from the House committee investigating the attack, which has heard testimony that President Donald J. Trump wanted agents to take him to the Capitol that day.
content: WASHINGTON — Text messages sent and received by Secret Service agents around the time of the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol last year have been erased, an inspector general said on Thursday, prompting concern from the House committee investigating the assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter and Stephen Gandel
title: Big Banks Prepare for Downturn, but Don’t See Recession Yet
description: As profits slowed at Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase, executives said that lending to consumers and businesses remained healthy but that risks loomed “down the road.”
content: Slowing demand and sinking markets have put an end to a period of record-setting profits for the country’s biggest banks, but that doesn’t mean a recession is imminent, top bankers say, even if it may look like they are preparing for one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: For Young Offenders, Restitution Debts Can Present Crippling Obstacles
description: A new report asserts that ordering juvenile offenders to pay compensation to their victims often derails their lives, and victims’ rights groups see shortcomings as well.
content: WASHINGTON — Arabella Guevara spent much of her adolescence paying for her mistakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Oleksandr Chubko and Vera Mironova
title: Priests Once Aligned With Russia Come Under Suspicion in Ukraine
description: The Ukrainian Orthodox Church was once a dominant force in the country, but now officials suspect that some priests may be collaborating with Russia.
content: RIVNE, Ukraine — A priest doused in green dye during a Sunday liturgy. Another yanked out of his western Ukrainian church as the police stood by watching. A church attacked by vandals, who filled it with foam, plastered the walls with portraits of Stalin and later set it on fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Judge Issues Arrest Warrant for Tina Peters, the Colorado County Clerk Under Indictment
description: Ms. Peters, the Mesa County clerk accused of overseeing a breach of election equipment, went to Las Vegas this week to speak at an event. A judge said the trip violated her bond conditions.
content: A judge in Colorado issued an arrest warrant on Thursday for Tina Peters, the Mesa County clerk who is under indictment in relation to a breach of election equipment after the 2020 presidential contest, for violating conditions of her bond that prevented her from traveling without court approval.

title: Stripe, the payments start-up, lowers internal valuation 28 percent.

content: Stripe, a payments start-up that has been one of the most valuable privately held tech companies in Silicon Valley, has lowered its internal valuation 28 percent, according to a person with knowledge of the situation, in another sign of how the fluctuating stock market and economic uncertainty are affecting private companies.

content: After climbing for months, gasoline prices have declined for 28 days in a row, giving consumers a welcome break. Energy analysts say American consumers are spending $140 million less on gasoline daily than they were a month ago. But the trend could easily reverse, especially if a hurricane knocks out a refinery on the Gulf Coast, since global oil supplies remain fairly tight.

content: Last week, Mark Landler, The Times’s London bureau chief, was out to dinner with family when he received word that Boris Johnson, Britain’s prime minister, was suddenly in deep political peril because of two cabinet resignations. author: By Paisley Rekdal and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: Portrait of D17: Female, 37 Years Old
description: A meditation on skulls, in which the skulls themselves get to have an opinion.
content: This poem is part of a sonnet sequence that meditates on Andrea Modica’s photographs of skulls unearthed from the Colorado Mental Health Institute in Pueblo. In this sonnet (there’s a dropped line in the poem, making it technically 15 lines — one more than a traditional sonnet), the speaker compares two kinds of skulls: anonymous skulls at the Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum in Phnom Penh and the tagged and mounted skulls in Colorado. Paisley Rekdal’s poems are often struck with intellect, and this one is no different — in the second part of the poem during the volta, or the turn in a sonnet, the skulls are animated with their own opinions. The syntax mirrors a thinking mind. Note all the interruptions, from the em-dash after “rain,” to the commas, to the colon after “witnesses,” to the line breaks, as if to say that the only way to make sense of horror is to populate it with the turning language of logic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: With Prices Soaring, I.M.F. and Pakistan Reach Deal to Revive Loan Program
description: The long-awaited agreement could pave the way for the release of $1.17 billion to Pakistan as the country grapples with high inflation and political instability.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The International Monetary Fund said it had reached a staff-level agreement with the Pakistani government for the revival of a bailout program, providing a welcome reprieve to the country as it struggles with a cratering economy, depreciating currency, high inflation and political instability.

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Friends Were Terrible Guests. Why Won’t They Apologize?
description: After allowing close friends the use of a getaway home, a reader struggles to forgive their poor behavior as houseguests.
content: I let friends stay at my lake house for a long weekend while I was away. I returned to six loads of dirty laundry, furniture moved all over the place and a pile of water toys in my shed — without so much as a thank-you note for letting them stay. I was upset and let them know it. Not only did they fail to apologize, they criticized my reaction (and questioned the amount of laundry they had actually left). I feel gaslit. These people are like family to me, but I’m not sure I can forgive them. Their response to my complaint was worse than the original inconsiderate behavior. What can I do?

content: FOUNTAIN, Colo. — The local Army recruiting station was empty. The normally reliable recruiting grounds at the nearby Walmart were a bust. author: By Tali Farhadian Weinstein
title: A Rape Trial, and a Legal Travesty. In 1793.
description: John Wood Sweet’s “The Sewing Girl’s Tale” tells the story of an unusual prosecution in 18th-century New York — and its contemporary relevance.
content: In the early morning hours of Sept. 5, 1793, a couple of blocks from what is now New York’s City Hall, a gentleman with a reputation as a “rake” raped a 17-year-old seamstress whom he had carried into a brothel by force. No doubt countless cases like this one are lost to history — papers didn’t report on them, records (if anyone kept them) rarely exist, and they rarely went to trial. In fact, in the decade since the end of British rule, there had only been two sexual assault prosecutions in the city of New York. But this case was unusual for several reasons: Lanah Sawyer, the young victim, had the mettle to report the crime. The state prosecuted it vigorously. And an English lawyer newly arrived in America with a personal interest in rape prosecutions (his patron’s son was under indictment for the same) decided to take notes, producing the first published report of such a trial in the United States and the material for “The Sewing Girl’s Tale,” John Wood Sweet’s excellent and absorbing work of social and cultural history.

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Asian American Student Success Isn’t a Problem
description: White anxiety about student performance may be driving educational changes.
content: Over the past three years, as universities across the country have abandoned standardized test requirements and moved toward more holistic models for admission, a persistent yet largely unexamined question has arisen: Would these changes be happening if white students were at the top of the academic food chain? The performance gap between Asian American and white high school students on standardized tests has grown over the past decade. In 2018, for example, Asian American students, on average, scored 100 points higher on the SAT than white students. Just three years later, in 2021, that gap had risen by over 25 percent, to 127. Many of the universities that have dropped the SAT requirement have cited a desire for diversity and equity and a de-emphasis on hard-core academic competition. (This has always struck me as errant and, frankly, self-serving reasoning. If elite colleges actually want economically and racially diverse campuses free from the academic stressors that plague high school students, they should take their own advice and stop competing so fiercely to prove that they are the most exclusive places of higher learning in the world.)

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: 19 Easy and Cheap Dinner Ideas That Everyone Will Love
description: Hello, inflation.
content: Being a grown-up is so expensive these days. Maybe you’re out of work, paying off student loans, scrimping to pay for child care or setting aside money for a new car or a Tuscan vacation. Whatever the reason, so many of us are looking for ways to save money, and as food prices continue to rise, it’s not always easy. But it’s not just a magazine slogan, you really can eat well and spend less. In short, do what you can to get your pantry in order, reduce your food waste and aim to eat mostly vegetarian or make recipes that really “stretch” a cut of meat.

content: When Major League Baseball and the players’ union worked their way through the contentious negotiations for a new labor agreement this past off-season, one topic had to be deferred in order to avoid delaying the regular season. M.L.B. had long wanted to create an international draft, while the union had resisted those efforts. The sides agreed to decide the issue by July 25, which allowed for the regular season to proceed in April.

title: Corrections: July 14, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 14, 2022.
content: An article on March 9 about the discovery of the wreck of the Endurance, which sank in the Antarctic in 1915 during an expedition by the explorer Ernest Shackleton, misstated the point at which Shackleton joined Endurance on what would be the ship’s final voyage. He came aboard in Argentina; he was not on the ship when it left England. This correction was delayed, because the error was only recently brought to the attention of editors.
